column2: the first LEGO Dimensions Year 2 trailer was released the addition of Sonic the Hedgehog was kept as the final surprise reveal of the video. Frankly I&#39
column3: ve been excited to pick this pack up from that point on. While many of the later Sonic games have had limited success, in the 90s Sonic (and a certain red hatted plumber) were the two biggest computer game icons, as such I&#39
column4: m glad to see Sonic making his way to the LEGO world, even if it currently remains only in a limited way.

column1: As with all the Level Packs so far, only one minifigure is included, Sonic.

The figure is as good of a representation of the character as you could possible expect. The torso features a very basic chest print on the front and some back spikes and a small tail print to the rear. The spikes appear a little flat next to the molded head, but I think having an additional part made just for that small detail would have been excessive.

The Legs have used the dual molding to creat sonics red and white shoes while keeping the top of the legs blue. While this is probably the best result LEGO could achieve with the current techniques the lack of print on the inside and rear of the legs still leaves a little bit of unfinished detail, but it'
column2: s only a problem with close inspection.

column1: The new moulded head piece has an excellent sculpt, it certainly looks as accurate as any other toy of Sonic I have seen.

The first of the two vehicles included is a mini version of the Sonic Speedster. To anyone who is only familiar with the earliest incarnations of Sonic, this probably appears to be a rather pointless vehicle invented for this game. This is not actually the case, it is based on the Speed Star, which was originally created for the game

At this scale I think that the designers have made the LEGO version as true to the original material as possible. Even without the knowledge of the source material the Sonic Speedster is definitely well designed to look like a Sonic themed vehicle.
The second rebuild is the Blue Typhoon. I'
column2: ll admit, this build I am not a huge fan of, I didn&#39
column3: t recognise the name from any Sonic franchise I was aware of and the build doesn&#39

column1: A little research did show that the Blue Typhoon probably did take it'
column2: s roots from a Sonic franchise, the cartoon Sonic X featured a large star ship called the Blue Typhoon. To be fair a Microscale star ship is about what came to mind when I first looked at this build, but it bears absolutely no similarities to it&#39
column3: s namesake. This is one minor issue I have with a lot of the Dimensions packs, some of the alternate builds are completely random and restriced in design by the need to use the exact same parts as the main build.

column1: The third and final rebuild of this minibuild is the Moto Bug. Long term fans of the series might recognise the name as motobugs have appeared in a lot of Sonic media, right the way back to the first game. However, this is another build that is very different to it'
While this looks very different to a Motobug as they have previously appeared in Sonic titles, you can at least see elements that the designer has tried to incorporate.
Like the robotic enemy, the vehicle features claws at the front, large teeth and a rounded blue '
column3: to the front. For a very limited parts selection it&#39
column4: s not a terrible representation, but without the parts restriction something much better could easily be achieved.

column1: As soon as I saw images of this I recognised it as Tails'
column2: plane from Sonic 2. One of my favourite gaming memories is playing the Sky Chase Zone level on Sonic 2 so I was thrilled to see the plane included.

column1: The colouring of this build has taken more of an influence from the later games, but it'
column2: s similar enough to the original to satisfy fans of the older games too. As with all the Dimensions vehicles, the scale is a little cartoon like, the propeller in particular looks a little out of scale with the rest of the plane, but as a stylised Biplane at this scale the design is effective.

column1: Some small changes might have made the design more accurate, but with this kind of scale, and the alternate models in mind, I think this is a good enough representation.
The second rebuild of this give us a far better take on another Sonic enemy, Crabmeat.

This is one of my favourite Dimesions alternate builds. I think it has a strong resembelance to the original games. As another enemy that has appeared in multiple titles the choice to include it as an alternate build was a good idea, and I'
column3: d have ever considered the possibility of turning the Tornado into a Crabmeat. The digital element features a completely different design of Crabmeat as an in game enemy, which is much closer to the original, but obviously didn&#39
column4: t have such a heavey restriction on parts for the design.

column1: The final version of this vehicle is the Eggcatcher, a sort of flying robot of some kind.

column2: ve dug around the internet a bit and can find no mention of this aside from LEGO Dimensions, so of all the stuff included in the pack this seems to be the only one that has no connection to any existing source material. It&#39
column3: s not the most interesting vehicle, but the arms do make nice use of the new 1x1 round plate with bar (http://brickset.com/parts/6157554) to&nbsp
column4: allow quite a lot of posability&nbsp

column1: As well as digital versions of Sonic and the minibuild vehicles, this pack give you a whole new level to play, access to a Sonic world to explore and a Sonic Battle arena.

From trailers of this pack I had high hopes for the level, and I was definitely not disappointed. It is full of little easter eggs to a huge range of Sonic games, it even starts with the classic SEGA opening that fans of the Megadrive games can'
column2: t help but smile at. They very cleverly started the level on a facsimile of the Sonic 1 Greenhill Zone. While the speed doesn&#39
column3: t handel quite as well as a traditional Sonic game, I think Tt have done a good job of simulating a&nbsp
column4: bit of classic Sonic gaming into the LEGO Dimensions software.

column1: The further I played, the more my smile grew! After
column2: completing the first section of the level Sonic gets transported to Sonic 2 Bonus stage - running along a half pipe. This bought&nbsp
column3: back so many memories of playing the classic games, it has been so cleverly thought out.

column2: gameplay references a lot of later Sonic games too,&nbsp
column3: a lot of the supporting characters make an appearance, even some of the more obscure&nbsp
column4: characters like Big the Cat. But at&nbsp
column6: s core this is the sort of&nbsp
column7: experience that will appeal to anyone who has played any of the Sonic games. My favourite reference is in Sonic&#39
column8: s reaction to realising he&#39
column9: ll need to&nbsp

column1: As well as a lot of great Sonic reference, there is a lot of connection made to the LEGO Dimensions story too. Wyldstyle, Batman &
column2: Gandalf make a brief appearance and the main premise of the level involves Robotnik (yes I&#39
column3: m old enough to consider this the true name of Dr Eggman) having the keystone powers. The level also ends on a cliffhanger, leading me to believe that some more content (perhaps the mysterious connectable packs)
column4: will link a lot of the year two content into the main storyline.

column2: ve been looking forward to getting this since it was first rumoured and it&#39
column3: s definitely lived up to expectations. It seems (in the UK at least) that the year 2 Dimensions packs are following a pricing pattern more typical of video games than LEGO toys, so deals are becoming more readily available - this was available for preorder at 33% off. If you have any connection to the Sonic franchise I&#39
column4: d definitely recommend picking this up.

column1:
,TRUE,4,3,4,4,3 AdamDaLegoGuy","2017-06-04T02:01:21.583Z","Even better than what I expected","

Minifigure: This is the first minifigure of Sonic to ever have been released, and thank goodness Lego did it well. He doesn&rsquo
column2: t have much printing on him, which he should not, and his head mold actually looks just like Sonic.&nbsp
column3: I just wish Lego had used a Lord of the Rings ring piece and not a swim buoy.

column1: Builds: The plane build on the set looks better than what pictures assumed
column2: I thought the rotor would be flimsy and look awkward on the craft, but it was done well. The car cleverly uses pieces to make it not look bulky, but also give it enough volume for it to not&nbsp
column3: just look like an ordinary car.

column1: Gameplay: As good as the LEGO in the set is, the gameplay is what most of
column2: the $30 is worth in my opinion - which I did not expect. The level&nbsp
column4: just like the Sonic games: quickly paced with obstacles and challenges throughout the whole level. You fight the classic Robotnik (Dr. Eggman) and all of the voices for the characters are fitting. The adventure world is large, colorful, and screams Sonic. Not to mention that it is full&nbsp
column5: of areas to run around in as Sonic (because that&rsquo
column7: what we all want to do, right?&nbsp

column1: Overall: On the whole, both the physical and digital material that you get in this pack do a good job converting Sonic into Lego, and it very well
column2: may open the door for Sonic Lego sets in the future...

column8: >Set #71244 Sonic the Hedgehog Level Pack:
column9: ><span style=""color: rgb(68, 68, 68)
column13: > Continuing on with LEGO Dimensions Reviews after a bit of a hiatus, ahem, let us discuss the first official Level Pack released for Series 2. A Level Pack which is well received by many. Is it worth hunting down long after retail presence of Dimensions is long gone&hellip
column14: well hopefully this review will help inform you before going out to buy.

column8: >Box: The box is pretty much what I&rsquo
column9: ve said since day one. A very uniform and nicely designed package. It includes imagery of Sonic in LEGO form all over, on the front, on the back, you get a lot of very nice artwork on this box.

column8: >Instructions: These are, of course, the same design as every other set. Showing how to build the Minifigure and then telling you to continue in-game to build the models, with checklists on the back few pages to show you what is available in the other waves.
>There aren&rsquo
column9: t a lot of parts in this set, and nothing is unique or printed aside from the toy tag, but there are a nice number of red and blue elements if you were thinking of getting this for a parts pack I suppose.

column8: >Sonic the Hedgehog: This Minifigure is using a unique sculpted head. He has minimal printing for the rest of the body, with dual-molded legs and looks fairly impressive. Unfortunately there is a glaring flaw with this figure. Sonic is given a plain yellow toilet seat element to represent the gold rings common in his video game.

>Considering the One Ring from LotR and The Hobbit sets would be more thematically appropriate the other problem I have with this accessory is that the box art shows it in glittering gold matching the look of a Ring better. If LEGO had decided to cast this in pearl gold plastic it may have been better received. Oh sure, making it chrome might have been too costly, but at least the pearl gold plastic would have worked better than simple plain LEGO Yellow. (I don&rsquo
column9: t like the use of the toilet seat element for other reasons obviously, but would grudgingly accept it if it matched the box imagery.)

column8: >The Tornado: Tails&rsquo
column9: iconic Biplane is a common sight in many Sonic games. This model represents one of the earliest versions from the 16-bit era and its build is extremely satisfying. I loved building this model and find the steps extremely engaging while making Sonic&rsquo

column8: >Crabmeat: This takes the parts above to re-build it into a Badnick. One of Doctor Eggman&rsquo
column9: s iconic looking robots, this model&rsquo
column10: s build is relatively simple, but admittedly not very in-game accurate. We&rsquo
column11: ll get to that in the finished model section, but I find this build to be a tad weak.

column8: >Egg Catcher: Doctor Eggman&rsquo
column9: s got a new threat to fight Sonic, except Sonic has rebuilt it out of the parts of his plane so I guess he&rsquo
column10: s controlling it now. This model is fun looking and fun to build, the second strongest of the models in this trio of builds and I did enjoy it.

column8: >Sonic Speedster: If Sonic is the fastest thing alive (his old theme songs always mention this fact) then why does he need a race car? Build this model and find out, or, just build it. It&rsquo
column9: s pretty fun, and is a solid build capturing the look of the new vehicle in Sonic&rsquo
column10: s recent racing games fairly nicely.

column8: >Blue Typhoon: Apparently some of the mechanics in these racing games involve vehicles that can transform into other vehicles. So they incorporated that idea into Dimensions by having you rebuild the Speedster car into the Blue Typhoon hovercraft. It&rsquo
column9: s an ok model and the re-use of parts to build this one is fairly ingenious in certain respects, however the large car elements re-used does tend to limit the way you can actually make this model look good while still working as what it was designed to.

column8: >Still it&rsquo
column9: s a straightforward and simple build easily done once you&rsquo
column10: ve upgraded enough skills and abilities to unlock the in-game instructions. (Or cheat by looking it up online if you&rsquo
column11: d prefer to skip that step.)

column8: >Motobug: Another Badnick returns. Sonic built a friendly version out of his car slash hovercraft. It&rsquo
column9: s another interesting model to build, though again it doesn&rsquo
column10: t quite catch the look of the 16-bit model it&rsquo
column11: s attempting to emulate. The build however is to the point and extremely satisfying.

column8: >The Tornado &amp
column9: Alternate Builds: As plane models go we&rsquo
column10: ve seen quite a lot, but The Tornado is meant to be iconic and this model is no exception. I feel it to be the strongest out of the three, the Egg Catcher model is second strongest looking fairly similar to the model in-game. And it&rsquo
column11: s a fun little extra if you want to have a vehicle for Eggman to fight.

column8: >Crabmeat unfortunately is a really poor model once built. It does look like a crab, but it doesn&rsquo
column9: t look anything like what Crabmeat is supposed to look like in-game. (Here or in Sonic&rsquo
column10: s regular games.) The claws aren&rsquo
column11: t big enough, the model is too tall rather than squat and low to the ground like an actual crab should be, and the parts re-use is rather unfortunate. I suppose since the parts need to be used to make two other vehicles this is to be expected, but I hope if they ever re-visit Sonic in LEGO form for some kind of limited run D2C set or something they make much better buildable Badnicks.

column8: >Sonic Speedster &amp
column9: Alternate Builds: In comparison to the above, all three of these models work much better, even if Motobug is a bit weak. The Speedster is a faithful looking representation of Sonic&rsquo
column10: s race car, the Typhoon works well as a hover craft although the profile of the model is a bit odd due to the re-used elements in the build.

column8: >And as far as Motobug is concerned, aside from the colours this model is much closer to what an actual Motobug in-game would look like. The only downside is the need to stick the car&rsquo
column9: s wheels somewhere, a Motobug doesn&rsquo
column10: t have wheels, plural, it has one large central wheel under the beetle like shell that rolls it around. Because this is a three-in-one model they can&rsquo
column11: t make it this way otherwise you&rsquo
column12: d have spare parts left off the model when attached to the toy tag. Still it&rsquo
column13: d be nice to see LEGO tackle some Sonic sets, just to see what could be done without the need to re-use bits in 3-in-1 builds.

column8: >The Level: The packaging calls this level Sonic&rsquo
column9: s the Name, Speed&rsquo
column11: t. In-Game I believe it was called Sonic Dimensions or something to that effect, I&hellip
column12: admittedly forgot to jot that down in my notes.

column8: >Ahem. The level however is fairly impressive. We get to re-visit many eras of Sonic in LEGO form, with Green Hill Zone, the Chaos Emerald Bonus Stage from Sonic 2, the Death Egg and even some areas found in Sonic Adventure. It&rsquo
column9: s extremely fun, and very engaging, also quite a lengthy level. Really impressed with it, however&hellip

column8: >Adventure World: The adventure world is where you get even way more experiences with Sonic. You can visit Green Hill, Chemical Plant, Angel Island, Lava Reef, Ice Cap, Carnival Night and just hop from one area to the next as you solve puzzles, help with other character quests and experience the thrill and (frustration) of Sonic races.
>This place is great, almost, I will admit that when you&rsquo
column9: re running with Sonic the camera just seems to have trouble keeping up with him some of the time. But honestly if you&rsquo
column10: re a fan of Sonic this LEGO version shows off a lot of the charm and fun of those games in Dimensions.

column8: >Battle Arena: Carnival Night Zone is where you and three of your friends or family can fight to capture the flags&hellip
column9: or whatever these things involve. Honestly I still never ventured into the Battle Arenas because I am a solo player and don&rsquo
column10: t have many options for multiplayer. Still this aspect of Series 2 is a nice addition and adds more play value to the game.

column8: >Character &amp
column9: Vehicle Abilities: Sonic&rsquo
column10: s abilities in this game includes Speed (naturally), Acrobat, Destroy Cracked LEGO Objects and can use a new ability known as Grind Rails. A character trait Sonic is well known for in most modern era games. You can do tricks and gain points, but mostly it&rsquo
column11: s used in this game for the Sonic Races. And boy are those things annoying.

column8: >Sonic Speedster can use Accelerator Switches and the Tow-Bar ability. As the Blue Typhoon you can activate Flight Docks and use Flight Cargo Hooks, has Sonar Smash, Tow-Bar and Sails on water. And once you turn it into a Motobug you can Dig, Super Jump and use Vine Cut.

>The Tornado is a flying vehicle, so default abilities include Flight Docks and Flight Cargo Hooks while also being able to use the Flying version of the Tow-Bar ability. Crabmeat in-game can Jump, Super Jump, Destroy Gold LEGO Objects and has the Guardian Ability. The Egg Catcher shares all of the abilities of The Tornado but also gains the Electricity Switches ability since it can shoot lightning.
>This set is a must have to complete LEGO Dimensions 200%, though the game still just says 100%. However if you aren&rsquo
column9: t interested in playing LEGO Dimensions as a game, I would still say that if you want a Sonic Minifigure you&rsquo
column10: re going to want this set. The models are also very impressive in this set despite some weaknesses in the Badnick designs.

column8: >I&rsquo
column9: d strongly recommend this set because the in-game content is really enjoyable. For the most part. Sonic Races are a frustrating irritation caused mainly by faulty camera controls when Sonic is racing, you&rsquo
column10: ll find the camera zipping all over the place screwing up your directional controls which makes running at Sonic speeds in this game extremely irritating. But still well worth the price of admission. So. Strongly Recommended.

This Sonic Minifigure Is One Of My Favourite Minifigures Ever And Defiantly The Best Dimensions Figure! The Build Isn'
